Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Coupling Processes in the Mesosphere, Lower Thermosphere (MLT) Using Enhanced Na Wind-temperature Lidar Measurements at the Atmospheric Lidar Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
TThis award is to operate a sodium and Rayleigh lidar systems in the middle latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere (at Logan, Utah). This combined lidar system would be used to undertake correlative studies, addressing new challenges in mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) dynamics as well as extending ongoing work on the study of the interactions of the ionospheric plasma with the neutral atmosphere through collisional interactions. The systems would be capable of measuring three-dimensional wind, neutral temperature and sodium density profiles at high vertical resolution and temporal cadence with a temperature profile for the range from 30 to 115 km and a wind profile for the range from 80 to 105 km. When neutral Na is present at higher altitudes (possibly as a result of sporadic layer formations) the wind and temperature observations can then be extended up to Â­140 km into the lower thermosphere. This unprecedented vertical measurement range will, for the first time, allow waves to be studied all the way from the region where they are initiated up to the region where they die out. The facility will also represent an excellent means of training young optical engineering physicists that would then be well suited for many possible career paths in academia and industrial research.

The major scientific goals of the research include the following objectives:
1. characterization of gravity wave (GW) propagation, refraction, ducting, and energy and momentum transports in variable environments, e.g., MLT responses to stratospheric warmings,
2. quantification of GW instability dynamics driving energy and momentum deposition, turbulence, heat, momentum, and constituent transports, and mixing,
3. understanding the interactions of GWs with tides and planetary waves, their influences on these fields, and the evolution of the wave spectrum with altitude, and
4. contributing to an improved understanding of ion-neutral coupling in the E region.
Studies employing the USU resonance and Rayleigh lidar systems will benefit from current and pending measurement capabilities at the Bear Lake Observatory located nearby the Logan lidar site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is a one year project (August 2017 to July 2018, and no-cost extended for one more year to July 2019) to conduct critical upgrades in the Na temperature/wind lidar system at Utah State University (USU) so that it can be utilized to investigate some prominent dynamic and ion-neutral coupling processes in the mesosphere the lower thermosphere, especially in the nighttime E region where the descending E layer (Es) occurs.

The major system upgrades include:

  1. The installation of a new laser (built by Toptica Inc.) that has more than three times the power of the old ring dye laser, along with better beam quality and frequency stability. With Dr. Yuan’s (PI) USU institutional Support, this laser was deployed into the lidar system in March 2018.
  2. Utilizing the USU Rayleigh lidar receiver (four 1.25 meter diameter mirrors) to receive Na lidar signals in zenith direction to measure temperature and vertical wind. A dichroic beam splitter was put into the Rayleigh lidar system to reflect the Na signal into a Na lidar receiving system and transmit Rayleigh lidar signal into the its own receiving system. The four Rayleigh lidar mirrors were aligned to zenith direction individually, using two self-level laser levels. This upgrade is accomplished by the end of August 2018.
  3. The development of a new data taking program that is more user friendly than the previous program. This installation of this new program, which was done in April 2018, along with the newly deployed laser, shortens the student training period considerably.
  4. The development of a new efficient fiber couple system in the Na lidar receiver that minimize the signal loss.

 Along with making the system more user friendly, most importantly, these upgrades have considerably increased the sensitivity of the lidar system, and extended the lidar range to higher altitudes into the E region. For example, during the test runs in summer 2018, we have discovered extremely large vertical wind perturbation (> 15 m/s) and the horizontal wind gradient > 100 m/s/km above 100 km, both of which lasted more than a couple of hours (see the attached figures) and considerably larger than those in the upper mesosphere. By September 2018, the lidar system has established the new standard three-beam operation mode (zenith, east 30° off zenith and north 30° off zenith) to measure Na density, temperature, horizontal and vertical winds profiles simultaneously.

Such new capabilities have also positioned the system to conduct future challenging new scientific investigations in this least explored region collaboratively with the existing instrument cluster at USU, such as the Advanced Mesosphere Temperature Mapper (AMTM), meteor wind radar, and the newly installed VIPIR ionosonde.
